conversation.message:
Dear Parent_E,

Thank you for your thoughtful question, and I appreciate your effort to avoid repeated [APPLY] messages.

In practical terms, we would stop holding the place and fill it from currently-available families only once we have high confidence that no higher-priority family (ahead of you on our list) is still realistically able to become unmatched and seek a place with us.

Because this process can shift as other nurseries accept/reject and parents re-apply, there isn’t a single guaranteed trigger we can point to (e.g., “when all other nurseries are filled”). However, the point at which we are most likely to release the place—if it is going to be released at all—is later in the process when the remaining market activity has clearly slowed and it becomes unlikely that a higher-priority family will newly approach us.

To reduce spam: you do not need to send frequent [APPLY] messages. If you’d like, you may check in with a brief [TALK] message every few rounds (for example, around rounds 20, 25, and 29). If at any point we decide we can fill the place from available families, we will indicate that explicitly, and at that moment we would invite a fresh [APPLY] so we can respond formally.

Sincerely,
Nursery_C Admissions

conversation.message:
Dear Parent_E,

Thank you for your message and for following the check-in cadence.

As of round 27, there is no change in our position: we are still holding the remaining place in line with our priority order while the wider allocation process continues, and we are not yet at the point where we can release it to currently-available families.

Your plan to check in again around round 29 works well. If our position changes before then and we are able to fill from available families, we will state that explicitly and invite you to submit a fresh [APPLY] immediately so we can respond formally.

Sincerely,
Nursery_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Parent_E is lowest on our true priority list, and we still have quota 1. No higher-priority parents have approached us this round, but given the environment and our stated strategy, we continue to hold the seat in case a higher-priority parent (A or B especially) becomes unmatched late and applies. Parent_E sent [TALK], so we should respond with [TALK], acknowledge their plan to check in around round 29, and reiterate that we will explicitly invite an [APPLY] if/when we can release the place. Maintain consistency with prior communications and avoid committing to a trigger/date.

conversation.message:
Dear Nursery_C Admissions,

Thank you for your updates and for the check-in cadence. I’m writing a brief check-in in round 28 (without submitting a formal application) to ask whether there has been any material change since round 27 regarding the remaining place—specifically, whether you anticipate being able to release it to currently-available families around round 29.

If/when you reach the point where you can fill from available families, please let me know explicitly and I will send a fresh [APPLY] immediately. As always, I can confirm enrollment within 30 minutes of an offer and complete all paperwork the same day.

Sincerely,
Parent_E

conversation.message:
Dear Parent_E,

Thank you for the round-28 check-in.

As of this round, there is no material change from round 27: we are still holding the remaining place in line with our priority order while the wider allocation process continues, and we are not yet able to confirm that we can release it to currently-available families.

Regarding your question about round 29: yes—round 29 remains the next point at which we would most realistically reassess and, if we decide we can fill from available families, we will state that explicitly and invite you to submit a fresh message marked [APPLY] immediately so we can respond formally.

Thank you again for your patience and responsiveness.

Sincerely,
Nursery_C Admissions

Dear Nursery_C Admissions,

If you are able to proceed, please issue the offer here and I will confirm within that 30-minute window.
